sub_topic: Identifying the perfect matching in a graph.
message_1: Consider a graph G with 8 vertices and 12 edges. Determine whether or not the graph G has a perfect matching.

A perfect matching in a graph is a set of edges such that every vertex is incident to exactly one edge in the set, and no two edges share a vertex. In other words, a perfect matching is a matching that covers all the vertices of the graph.

A necessary condition for a graph to have a perfect matching is that it must have an even number of vertices. In this case, the graph G has 8 vertices, which is even, so it is possible for G to have a perfect matching.

However, we need to check if there are any other conditions that might prevent G from having a perfect matching.
